metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dateset of GPR (Ground Penetration Radar) observations in the A'rou foci experimental area from Mar to Jun , 2008
metadata.description:
The dateset of GPR (Ground Penetration Radar) observations was obtained in the A'rou foci experimental area from Mar. 10 to Jun. 19, 2008. Those provide reliable dataset for retrieval of soil moisture and frozen depth from GPR observations.
    Observation items, sites and time were as follows:
     (1) GPR in No. 1 quadrate of A'rou on Mar. 10, 2008
     (2) GPR+TDR in No. 2 and 3 quadrates of A'rou on Mar. 11, 2008
     (3) GPR in No. 1 quadrate of A'rou on Mar. 12, 2008
     (4) GPR in No. 2 quadrate of A'rou on Mar. 14, 2008
     (5) GPR +TDR in No. 1 quadrate of A'rou on Mar. 15, 2008
     (6) GPR +TDR in L6 of A'rou on Mar. 16, 2008
     (7) GPR +TDR in L6 of A'rou on Mar. 17, 2008
     (8) GPR +TDR in L6 of A'rou on Mar. 18, 2008
     (9) GPR +TDR in L6 of A'rou on Mar. 19, 2008
     (10) GPR in L6 of A'rou on Mar. 20, 2008
     (11) GPR +TDR in No. 3 quadrate of A'rou on Mar. 21, 2008
     (12) GPR in No. 1 and 3 quadrates of A'rou on May. 31, 2008
     (13) GPR in No. 1 quadrate of A'rou on Jun. 20, 2008

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used for observing soil moisture and freezing depth in cold regions?
Concept Completion.Answer: Ground Penetrating Radar Time Domain Reflectometry

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used for GPR and TDR observations in hydrological research?
Feature Specification.Answer: accuracy in capturing variations in soil moisture, observations made at specific sites, period from March to June

Quantification.Question: How many days of GPR and TDR observations were conducted in the 阿柔加密观测区 during the 2008 period?

Definition.Question: What does 'GPR' mean in the context of data collection methods for hydrological experiments?
Definition.Answer: GPR stands for Ground Penetrating Radar, which is a data collection method used in hydrological experiments to observe and collect data related to soil moisture and freezing depths. It provides essential ground data for the development and validation of inversion techniques using GPR data.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques using ground-penetrating radar (GPR) compare to those using time-domain reflectometry (TDR) in terms of effectiveness for soil moisture and freezing depth detection in cold regions?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection using ground-penetrating radar (GPR) focuses on detecting subsurface features such as soil moisture and freezing depth through radar wave reflection. Time-domain reflectometry (TDR) measures soil moisture by evaluating the dielectric constant of the soil. The combination of GPR and TDR techniques provides comprehensive data, with GPR offering spatial coverage and TDR providing point-specific moisture content. The use of both methods on different dates and locations suggests a complementary approach to enhance data reliability and accuracy in detecting soil conditions in cold regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the accuracy of soil moisture and freezing depth retrieval when integrating GPR and TDR data collection methods over a period of several months?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating GPR and TDR data collection methods over a period of several months allows for more comprehensive ground truth data, which can improve the accuracy of soil moisture and freezing depth retrieval. This is due to the ability to cross-validate and calibrate GPR data with direct measurements from TDR, reducing uncertainty and enhancing the reliability of the inversion models used.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect GPR and TDR data in the context of hydrological studies in cold regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting GPR and TDR data is crucial for developing and validating methods to invert soil moisture and freezing depth, which are key parameters in understanding hydrological processes in cold regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures and instruments are used to collect and ensure the accuracy of GPR and TDR data for hydrological studies in cold regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the specified field, GPR (Ground-Penetrating Radar) and TDR (Time Domain Reflectometry) were used to collect data on soil moisture and freezing depth. Observations were conducted over specific dates and locations, such as Arou sample plots and transects, to gather comprehensive ground data needed for developing and validating inversion models using GPR data.
